summary: The documents mention 'Telegram' primarily as a medium of communication used by various individuals and organizations. These telegrams serve diverse purposes, including claiming responsibility for sabotage (MIRR telegram to the Associated Press), conveying urgent information about political situations (CIA telegrams regarding South Vietnam and Cambodia), providing instructions for surveillance and communications (cable from the Director), and addressing financial matters (memo and telegram regarding payment to Edvard G. Tichborn). The telegrams highlight the importance of rapid communication and information dissemination in intelligence and political operations during the period.
significance: In the context of the JFK assassination, the significance of 'Telegram' lies in its role as a tool for communication and information exchange within intelligence agencies and other organizations. While none of the documents directly link telegrams to the assassination itself, they illustrate how critical information was transmitted and decisions were made during the period leading up to and following the event. The telegrams related to political instability in South Vietnam are of particular interest given the broader geopolitical context of the assassination.
